instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC Resets when physically touching <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, and <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>, and its surroundings.
threads.message:
When I touch, with my finger, <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, or <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>, the SMC will reset

Its actually seems like the SMC turns on, then off, then on again. 

This board had a history of liquid damage, there seems to be no damage around <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, and its surroundings, however on <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>, the chip itself seems fine, but <CAPACITOR>C7094</CAPACITOR> seems like it has been charred, however is still outputting correct voltage. 

The Macbook does have fan spin, but does not power up or show image, CPU gets warm though. Fans spin really fast too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC Resets when physically touching <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, and <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>, and its surroundings.
threads.message:
Do you get correct and stable <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>?
<SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> is good?

Change <CAPACITOR>C7094</CAPACITOR>, it is very important.

Did you test for USB activity (both ports)?
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_BUF_L</SIGNAL> go both high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC Resets when physically touching <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, and <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>, and its surroundings.
threads.message:
Yes I get a stable 3.4V

<SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> reads at 3.2V which is the same for me on a working board.

I will change <CAPACITOR>C7094</CAPACITOR>.

No USB activity at all. I have already removed J6100 due to corrosion, and <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> looks fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC Resets when physically touching <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, and <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>, and its surroundings.
threads.message:
I may be mentally handicapped... You can reset this on a working board by using your finger :mad:

But still, no image, and the fan does spin to the max. I replaced <CAPACITOR>C7094</CAPACITOR>, <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, and <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>, so we know for sure thats good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC Resets when physically touching <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, and <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>, and its surroundings.
threads.message:
<CHIP>U5110</CHIP> inputs are very sensitive; if you touch them, can trigger the output reset.

Corrosion near J6100 could affected opposite side.
Check all SPI Bus Serie Termination resistors and traces.
Also try FULL known good working BIOS, with clean ME.
